bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to M.A. Barber, February 2, 1922

div1.p: Carter discusses Kudo's article, as well as others. Carter would like to work with Barber for a short period, although he believes a winter attack on Anopheles is fruitless.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to M.A. Barber, February 2, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
Mal.
Barber
2121 California St., N. W.
,D. C.l
February 2, 1922.
Dear Doctor Barber:
div1.p:
I am herewith returning Kudo's article, which really seems to me
to be good, and your so-wonderful picture of the ladies useful in
military transportation. Do you know, I think Roubaud might have used
them as “protective animals” as well as stock!

Joking aside, if you will look on Pages 178 and '79 you will see
that Kudo gives a fair basis for the somewhat lurid account in the
Times. Well, natural enemies be multiplied!--and this parasite
may be an adjuvant. It would act in grassy and algae-covered places
where fish would not.

I judge my Abstracts on Roubaud's and LeGendre's articles are
out. The one published in /20 can scarcely be held to be recent lit-
erature, but I felt quite certain the men in the field had not seen
it and added the one of 1918 as containing his claim that these Ano-
pheles were readily infectable and infective.

I have not seen the one you alluded to--Bul. Soc. Path. Exot.
XIV: 1921, 577--as the last one in the Surgeon General's Library goes
only to Page 451 and they haven't it at the Congressional Library.
Netiher have I been able to see the original of
in the Memoires of the Danish Royal Academy as that Journal had not
been received at any of the four places I have tried: Agriculture:
Carnegie and the other two.

I would like well to go down to Camilla and work with you for
a month or so.

I profoundly disbelieve that the winter attack on Anopheles is
worth much where the breeding season is so long as we have it; for things
that breed as rapidly as they do the number that commences the season
simply affects the date at which the maximum density occurs--scarcely
the maximum density itself. The limit to the density of Anopheles a-
round Camilla would be given by something else than the number of fe-
males available for oviposition--probably available area of breeding
places. It is doubtless worth while where the breeding season is short.

Possibly hand catching or “swatting” of those found in dwelling
houses in the early spring (hibernated females) might prevent a certain
amount of the early spring malaria, thus leaving fewer carriers to in-
fect the first flight of Anopheles.

It is possible that the parasite may survive the winter in the in-
sect host as far south as Camilla, but I was thinking rather of the un-
infected hibernated females, early infected and spreading infection be-
fore they die.

Give my love to Theodore Hayne, who I thought was studying at
Charleston.

By the way, I had a copy of your article on the use of Paris green
sent to everyone engaged or interested in malaria work on the mailing
list of the Bureau. It was given to me to abstract, but I thought the
article itself would do far better than any abstract of it.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Address:
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
